Posts.Content: i would like to ask your opinion. i took my psa on may 25th. the results came back today as a 10.84 my uro prescribed me with cipro, because he believes it may be an infection. i'm instructed to take it once every 12hrs for two weeks, then come back july 3rd. for another psa testing. from my understanding cipro don't always bring down the psa or doesn't do a good job of treating infections. if you take a look at my signature, that would give you a good idea of my history. last friday, my urinalysis showed that i had leukocytes in my urine. the urine was taken for a culture, but came back negative. so, if the test came back negative, but the psa is ten, why would my uro think it may be an infection? if my psa was 7.74 in november, and 10.84 in may, that is a 3.1 spike. shouldn't that be a concern? my uro also performed a dre after having blood drawn. he said everything felt smooth and normal with the exception of a slight enlargement. he went on to say that it was to be expected considering my age and that i have bph. what R your thoughts on this matter?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Cipro is a powerful antibiotic, but it often has no effect on prostatitis. I have read that about 90 percent of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics...What is your prostate density (PSAD)? Your prostate volume should have been noted on your MRI. my prostate volume is 31mL. this was noted in may of 2017 on my MRI. if 90% of prostate inflammation cases do not involve bacteria and do not respond to antibiotics, then why am i being prescribed with cipro? it seems to be a waste of time to take the drug. it would seem that i am just taking it to have something written on paper. i'm not saying this at you, but that doesn't help my anxiety.

Posts.Content: hello, i have my results of the biopsy. my report says 6 of the 8 cores taken are gleason 7 prostate cancer. here's the rest of what was said and written. i down't know how to attach the pathology report for everyone to C. that's quite a bit to copy. i'm scared and sad. i don't know what to do. This letter is a follow-up to our telephone call today 2/28/2019. As I discussed with you, your pathology results for your prostate biopsy indicates that SIX of your EIGHT sample cores were positive for prostatic adenocarcinoma (prostate cancer). The severity of prostate cancer is graded on a scale from 2 to 10 called the Gleason Score. Prostate cancer with Gleason Scores 7 through 10 are considered ones in which medical intervention is required. SIX of your prostate samples from the three lesions previously identified by MRI prostate had Gleason Scores of 7 or greater. Medical intervention is typically radiation therapy or radical prostatectomy (surgical removal of the entire prostate). However, these are not the only treatment options available to patients. Your earlier MRI of prostate indicated that there was no evidence of spread of cancer beyond the prostate to the lymph nodes or pelvic bones. This is great news! You have informed me that you will contact me early the week of March 4th 2019 to inform me who you would like to meet with for the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic appointment. I can schedule you with Dr. Sanda, Dr. Patteras or Dr. Filson. The purpose of the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic:  To inform patient of all available treatment choices  To help patient evaluate all the treatment options  To answer questions about available therapies  To help patient with choosing a treatment option What we recommend between now and your appointment is to do your own research on the following topics. Prostate cancer, radiation therapy for prostate cancer, prostatectomy, recovery time after prostatectomy, and Gleason Scores. This research will help you formulate questions to ask the doctor that you meet with at the follow-up. We encourage you to bring either a spouse, fiancee, family member or friend to your follow-up appointment. This will allow you to focus your attention on the discussion with the doctor while your guest can capture notes and provide emotional support. A copy of your pathology report for prostate biopsy is attached. Listed is a link that may be helpful in your research about prostate cancer: https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/C...ic/8796.00.pdf Please let me know if you have any questions in regard to your results. Sincerely, Jan Johnson, NP-C Attachments Pending Approval (2-25-2019) Anat Path Reports.pdf (9.4 KB)

Posts.Content: 1. Getting a 2nd opinion on your biopsy pathology from Dr. J. Epstein at Johns Hopkins. 2. Having a genomics test done to check the tendency of your cancer to form metastases. Note that this doesn't have to be done, and is probably more accurate when done on your removed prostate if you choose surgery. RT is the other treatment path, with several types of radiation to choose from. If that is your choice, the genomics test can be done on your biopsied tissue at any time. 3. Ask what imaging your doc thinks need to be done, such as CTs and possibly a bone scan. The latter might depend on whether your G7 is a (3+4) or a (4+3) -- as you probably know, the more prevalent tumor grade is listed first. 1. i can't afford to travel if dr. j. epstein is out of town. plus i'm on georgia medicaid. i doubt if they pay for anything outside of my state. 3. i tried to attached my pathology report, buy my PCa is 4+3=7

Posts.Title: My Biopsy Results Are In

Posts.Content: hello, i have my results of the biopsy. my report says 6 of the 8 cores taken are gleason 7 prostate cancer. here's the rest of what was said and written. i down't know how to attach the pathology report for everyone to C. that's quite a bit to copy. i'm scared and sad. i don't know what to do. This letter is a follow-up to our telephone call today 2/28/2019. As I discussed with you, your pathology results for your prostate biopsy indicates that SIX of your EIGHT sample cores were positive for prostatic adenocarcinoma (prostate cancer). The severity of prostate cancer is graded on a scale from 2 to 10 called the Gleason Score. Prostate cancer with Gleason Scores 7 through 10 are considered ones in which medical intervention is required. SIX of your prostate samples from the three lesions previously identified by MRI prostate had Gleason Scores of 7 or greater. Medical intervention is typically radiation therapy or radical prostatectomy (surgical removal of the entire prostate). However, these are not the only treatment options available to patients. Your earlier MRI of prostate indicated that there was no evidence of spread of cancer beyond the prostate to the lymph nodes or pelvic bones. This is great news! You have informed me that you will contact me early the week of March 4th 2019 to inform me who you would like to meet with for the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic appointment. I can schedule you with Dr. Sanda, Dr. Patteras or Dr. Filson. The purpose of the Multidisciplinary Prostate Cancer Clinic:  To inform patient of all available treatment choices  To help patient evaluate all the treatment options  To answer questions about available therapies  To help patient with choosing a treatment option What we recommend between now and your appointment is to do your own research on the following topics. Prostate cancer, radiation therapy for prostate cancer, prostatectomy, recovery time after prostatectomy, and Gleason Scores. This research will help you formulate questions to ask the doctor that you meet with at the follow-up. We encourage you to bring either a spouse, fiancee, family member or friend to your follow-up appointment. This will allow you to focus your attention on the discussion with the doctor while your guest can capture notes and provide emotional support. A copy of your pathology report for prostate biopsy is attached. Listed is a link that may be helpful in your research about prostate cancer: https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/C...ic/8796.00.pdf Please let me know if you have any questions in regard to your results. Sincerely, Jan Johnson, NP-C Attachments Pending Approval (2-25-2019) Anat Path Reports.pdf (9.4 KB)

Posts.Content: 1. Getting a 2nd opinion on your biopsy pathology from Dr. J. Epstein at Johns Hopkins. 2. Having a genomics test done to check the tendency of your cancer to form metastases. Note that this doesn't have to be done, and is probably more accurate when done on your removed prostate if you choose surgery. RT is the other treatment path, with several types of radiation to choose from. If that is your choice, the genomics test can be done on your biopsied tissue at any time. 3. Ask what imaging your doc thinks need to be done, such as CTs and possibly a bone scan. The latter might depend on whether your G7 is a (3+4) or a (4+3) -- as you probably know, the more prevalent tumor grade is listed first. 1. i can't afford to travel if dr. j. epstein is out of town. plus i'm on georgia medicaid. i doubt if they pay for anything outside of my state. 3. i tried to attached my pathology report, buy my PCa is 4+3=7

Posts.Content: hello, on wednesday aug. 22nd, i had a 3T MRI done on my prostate. here are the results. i wanted to send it via attachment, but i g uess the file is too big. so, i will copy everything i see. i haven't spoken with my uro yet, 'cause i asked for the records before the uro office called me. please tell me what all of this means. i'm afraid to say the least. ================================================== ==== "FINDINGS": "please note diffusion imaging is limited at the mid glad and apex due to artifact from adjacent bowel gas" THE PROSTATE GLAND overall sizeprostate dimensions = 4.7 X 3.5 X 4.3cm {maximum transverse, anteroposterior, and cranioucaudal dimensions, respectively} PERIPHERAL ZONE: no T1 hyper-intensity in the peripheral zone. peripheral zone focal abnormalities lesion 1 size: .9 X .8cm location: left apex at 3:00 o'clock REPORT multiparametric MRI features: T2-WIs: dark {series 4 image 11} DWI: bright {series 6 image 62} ADC map: dark {series 7 image 10} DCE-MRI: negative pi-rads:4 lesion 2 size: .9 X .6cm location: right mid gland at 10:00 oclock multiparametric MRI features T2-WIs: dark {series 4 image 15} DWI mildly bright {series 6 image 66} ADC map: mildy dark {series 7 image 14} DCE-MRI: negative pi-rads: 3 lesion: 3 size: 2.5 X 1.1cm location: diffuse left mid gland multiparametric MRI features: T2-WIs: dark {series 4 image 17} DWI: mildly bright {series 6 image 68} ADC map: mildly dark {series 7 image 16} DCE-MRI: negative pi-rads:3 central gland: no changes of BPH no central gland abnormalities *extraprostatic tumor extension: none *neurovascular bundles: normal *seminal vesicles: normal *urinary bladder: normal *pelvic lymphadenopathy: none *enhancing pelvic bone lesions: none other incidental findings: mildly prominent bilateral inguinal lymph nodes are nonspecific and may be reactive. IMPRESSION: 1. 3 peripheral zone focal abnormalities, one of which has multiparametric MRI findings with a pi-rad 4 lesion and two of which have multiparametric MRI findings consistent with pi-rads 3 lesions. 2. no evidence of extraprostatic disease, pelvic lymphadenopathy, or enhancing pelvic bone lesions. ================================================== =========== all those are my 3T MRI results. would you PLEASE help me to understand what's going on? i'm scared, you guys.

Posts.Title: Apifiny Non-PSA Blood Exam

Posts.Content: hello, good people. i would like to share with you my MRI/Ultrasound fusion targeted biopsy experience. as some of you may know, there were three lesions found on my prostate during my 3T mpMRI. one was a PI-RADS 4 and the other two were a PI-RADS 3. well, my uro recommended i have a MRI/Ultrasound fusion targeted biopsy. my uro who performed the biopsy was dr. cara cimmino. she and i discussed my situation and she decided in order to prevent risk, she would only target the three legions and not take anymore samples. so she prescribed me bactrim for the antibiotic, magnesium citrate for a laxative and two pills of valium to reduce anxiety. i was scheduled to take the laxative the night before. i had water diarrhea. for most of the night, but luckily, it subsided 'round 2am eastern time. the bactrim i took at the next morning at 8am and i waited to get to the hosp. to start the procedure before i took the valium. right B4, dr. cimmino performed the biopsy, she performed a DRE and said that it felt normal. the nurse gave me an antibiotic shot, in my behind and numbed my rectal area. then she proceeded to perform the biopsy. she took like three samples from each lesion and told me that everything went well. she says the results should be back within a week. when i tell you i felt every nook and cranny, OMG. i thought the valium would knock me out. the valium didn't kick in until after the procedure was over. the biopsy took about 15 - 20 min. so, i'm guessing i'll know the results by this or next week.

Posts.Title: My MRI/Ultrasound Fusion Targeted Biopsy Experience

Posts.Content: hello, good people. i would like to share with you my MRI/Ultrasound fusion targeted biopsy experience. as some of you may know, there were three lesions found on my prostate during my 3T mpMRI. one was a PI-RADS 4 and the other two were a PI-RADS 3. well, my uro recommended i have a MRI/Ultrasound fusion targeted biopsy. my uro who performed the biopsy was dr. cara cimmino. she and i discussed my situation and she decided in order to prevent risk, she would only target the three legions and not take anymore samples. so she prescribed me bactrim for the antibiotic, magnesium citrate for a laxative and two pills of valium to reduce anxiety. i was scheduled to take the laxative the night before. i had water diarrhea. for most of the night, but luckily, it subsided 'round 2am eastern time. the bactrim i took at the next morning at 8am and i waited to get to the hosp. to start the procedure before i took the valium. right B4, dr. cimmino performed the biopsy, she performed a DRE and said that it felt normal. the nurse gave me an antibiotic shot, in my behind and numbed my rectal area. then she proceeded to perform the biopsy. she took like three samples from each lesion and told me that everything went well. she says the results should be back within a week. when i tell you i felt every nook and cranny, OMG. i thought the valium would knock me out. the valium didn't kick in until after the procedure was over. the biopsy took about 15 - 20 min. so, i'm guessing i'll know the results by this or next week.

Posts.Content: hello all my first appt. was this past wednesday. i met with dr. sanda at emory. but i also met with a dr. moghanaki, who's a radiation oncologist. VERY NICE guy. you know how much i value great bed side manner. well, dr. moghanaki came in first. he ask'd me a lot of questions about my health/family background. when i told him i have a history of colon cancer in my family, he recommended if i decide to choose radiation, i should first have a colonoscopy and a genetics test to see if i have that gene. what are your thoughts on that, PCa brothers? anyhow, dr. moghanaki went on to tell me about the different types of radiation they offer and its pros/cons. then in comes dr. sanda. he tells me about the surgery and its pros/cons. it was about an hr. long session. overall, it was a good session. i go to see, dr. hershatter another radiation oncologist, to get his opinion about my diagnosis and treatment. what questions should i ask, dr. hershatter?

Posts.Content: My MRI results came back today. The MRI came back normal. My URO wants me to keep my six month appointment. Thank you SO MUCH TO EVERYONE OF YOU who made a contribution to ease my mind and educate me on what I need to know about prostate cancer. I pray that one day I will be to somebody what you've been to me. It's not over yet, but I promise to keep you informed.

Posts.Title: My 3T MRI Procedure, Yesterday

Posts.Content: hello, good people. how are you? yesterday, i went to have my 3T MRI done. it was a fairly easy process. it was sort of a two part MRI: 1. there was a procedure done with contrast. 2. the second 1/2 was done without contrast. after the MRI, the tech created a CD copy given to me, so the next time i see my uro, he can have a copy. i was told to take gas-x for breakfast, lunch and dinner the day before the MRI, and take one gas-x pill the day of the MRI. the MRI lasted close to an hr. i was told to expect results within 24 - 48hrs. i tried to look at the MRI pictures and all i saw was a bunch of black and white huey/gooey. there was one picture i saw a highlighted round circle, but who knows what that could mean? i could use some encouragement. please help.

Posts.Title: BPH, Prostatitis and Different PCa Treatments

Posts.Content: Hello good people. i just had a thought run cross my mind. i have been reading about the different treatments for PCa. i'm still learning. never knew there were so many acronyms. sheeeeeesh. anyhow, N addition to my cancer, i still have BPH from 2014 and prostatitis that comes and goes. as we all know, those two conditions have an impact on PSA levels. my last PSA was taken around july 2018 and it was a 11.9. my question to you is if i were to choose a radiation treatment, would having the BPH and prostatitis prevent my PSA from going undetected?

Posts.Title: My PSA Results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hi Sw, did you also get a freePSA measure? That may indicate what is going on. hi, wilde. yes, i had a freePSA measured. here are the results.: 1/14/2016 15:44 Prostate Specific Antigen 7.66 ng/mL Free Prostate Specific Antigen 0.67 ng/mL Prostate Specific Antigen Ratio 8.7 % here's what my uro had to say to these results: PSA still high, with concerning free-fraction, making risk of having prostate cancer around 56% (normal risk with high PSA is around [30%). But you had inflammation on last biopsy, so the slightly higher PSA could easily come from that inflammation. There is another test performed on post-prostate massage urine sample that measures gene expression called PCA3 test. If the gene expression is low, the 75% negative predictive value that you do not have prostate cancer. If it is abnormal, then the 57% positive predictive value that you do have something. Thus, it is much better at reassuring us that there is nothing concerning there when negative, and sparing you from another biopsy. The PCA3 test is FDA approved, but insurance does not reimburse enough to cover the test, so patients are directly billed $175 for it. For most men, that price is worth it to avoid another biopsy. If you want to have that done, make an appointment for RV (return visit) and we can get that done quickly. If the PCA3 test is positive, then I would recommend getting a multi-parametric MR of the prostate which can identify suspicious areas for biopsy. We then would fuse the MR images with a 3-dimensional prostate ultrasound to get targeted biopsies of those suspicious areas rather than the 12 "template" biopsies with standard prostate sampling. You could skip the PCA3 test and go to the multi-parametric MR if you were concerned about the cost of the PCA3, but I think it is worth the price to avoid another biopsy if possible. so, i had a 2nd opinion from another urologist. his suggestion was to try a new blood test called Apifiny. this blood test is the only cancer specific, non-PSA blood test that measures specific biological markers known to be associated with an immune system response to prostate cancer. if the score is 0 - 59, this means i'm in a lower risk category for having PC. if the score is 60 - 100, this would place me in the higher category for having PC. my score was 41. so since my score was within this range, my uro decided to just monitor my PSA. should it rise, he will order a MRI.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Honeybun078 Pirad 4 is that high??!? yes, that's high. but does it ALWAYS mean cancer? NO! i had three lesions. the first was a pi-rads 4 and the other two were a pi-rads 3. the 4 was found to be benign while the other two were found to be cancer. when an MRI discovers lesions and are graded a PI-RADS 3 or better, it simply means one needs a biopsy. only a biopsy will determine if one has prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: hello, everybody. i want to say that i am thankful to be here. let me give you a run down of what has happened. last year, my PSA was 5.5, so i was scheduled to have a biopsy. my urologist diagnosed me with asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis and BPH. on june 24th of this year, i had my annual physical. i noticed on the lab results my primary doctor didn't check my PSA. when i asked my urologist, he said it should be checked within two years of the biopsy. i asked my primary doctor last week, to check my PSA anyway. well, today, the PSA results came back 5.9 let me also add that on june 24th, my WBC [white blood cell] was elevated at 11.9. so, this monday, my primary doctor wants to re-test my cell blood count. my question is if i have a higher PSA than last year, and my recent WBC was 11.9, should i be concerned that this time it may be something more serious? thank you so much, in advance. ===================================== 12.18.2013 | Turned 40 yrs. old 07.09.2014 | Annual physical 07.11.2014 | P.S.A. 5.5 Referred to Urologist 07.29.2014 | Urologist performed DRE found nothing. 08.19.2014 | Biopsy performed 08.25.2014 | Diagnosed with Asymptomatic Inflammatory Prostatitis & BPH

Posts.Content: i can't recall if i told any of you i had my 3T MRI this past may. when i first went to see my new uro, he said we would monitor the PSA. if my PSA remains at a 6 or below, we would just continue to monitor every 6 months. if my psa elevates to a 7 or above, then a 3T MRI would be ordered. well, in april my psa was a 7.26. as a matter of fact, here's a list of my past psa results: 03.2016 | PSA = 6.21 07.2016 | PSA = 6.92 10.2016 | PSA = 6.94 04.2017 | PSA = 7.26 (3T MRI ordered) 10.2017 | PSA = 7.74 i'm not sure how to send you a full copy of my 3T MRI results, so i'll just send you the parts that concerns me. prostate: size: 3.4 X 4.1 X 4.3cm volume: 31mL peripheral zone: normal. there is a mild diffuse increased perfusion of the left prostate gland that could be secondary to prostatitis. basically, the MRI was normal, but it suspected or saw prostatitis. when i went for my six month follow up on oct 10th, he tested my psa. i asked him what is the next plan. he said we will continue to monitor my psa every six months. if the psa rises to a 9 or above, he will prescribe some antibiotics to make sure it's inflammation. if my psa is still 9 or above he will have another 3T MRI and possibly a saturated biopsy. the psa results were a 7.74 i was so glad to know there was no need for a biopsy because of the results of my MRI, i didn't think to ask him, why won't he treat the inflammation, since he might suspect that may be the case if my PSA goes to a 9. the MRI said it saw prostatitis. it seems to me as if he's still monitoring for cancer and not treating the inflammation which may bring down the PSA. why does my psa keep elevating? i'm glad it's not a 9 and i'm MOST HAPPY it's not cancer, but i feel if he treats the prostatitis or inflammation, then maybe my psa'll go down. i take saw palmetto 320mg. my symptoms are not unbearable, but i would feel much better if we could find a better way to bring down my psa. what are your thoughts?

Posts.Title: My PSA Keeps Elevating

Posts.Content: Hello, everybody. Let me first wish you a very HAPPY NEW YEAR!! As some of you know, this past summer, I took the regular PSA and it turned out to be a 5.9, higher than the 5.5 PSA in July of. So, my uro, asked me to have a free/total PSA done in six months. Well, yesterday, I had my free/total PSA and I'd like to share with you the results. I'm not ashamed to say that I am scared and confused. Please share with me your thoughts. Here are the results and comments: Here are the comments my urologist emailed to me: PSA still high, with concerning free-fraction, making risk of having prostate cancer around 56% (normal risk with high PSA is around 30%). But you had inflammation on last biopsy, so the slightly higher PSA could easily come from that inflammation. There is another test performed on post-prostate massage urine sample that measures gene expression called PCA3 test. If the gene expression is low, the 75% negative predictive value that you do not have prostate cancer. If it is abnormal, then the 57% positive predictive value that you do have something. Thus, it is much better at reassuring us that there is nothing concerning there when negative, and sparing you from another biopsy. The PCA3 test is FDA approved, but insurance does not reimburse enough to cover the test, so patients are directly billed $175 for it. For most men, that price is worth it to avoid another biopsy. If you want to have that done, make an appointment for RV (return visit) and we can get that done quickly. If the PCA3 test is positive, then I would recommend getting a multi-parametric MR of the prostate which can identify suspicious areas for biopsy. We then would fuse the MR images with a 3-dimensional prostate ultrasound to get targeted biopsies of those suspicious areas rather than the 12 "template" biopsies with standard prostate sampling. You could skip the PCA3 test and go to the multi-parametric MR if you were concerned about the cost of the PCA3, but I think it is worth the price to avoid another biopsy if possible. Here are the Results of the actual Free/Total PSA: Date Result Name Value Ref Range 1/14/2016 15:44 Prostate Specific Antigen 7.66 ng/mL (0.00 - 4.00) 1/14/2016 15:44 Free Prostate Specific Antigen 0.67 ng/mL 1/14/2016 15:44 Prostate Specific Antigen Ratio 8.7 %

Posts.Content: on july 3rd, i had my psa re-tested and today, i found out the results are 11.9. so, my uro is recommending another 3T MRI. i don't understand what's going on. he put me on cipro for two weeks and it's my understanding that cipro doesn't help bring down the PSA depending on the type of prostatitis one may have. plus, i was told by my general physician my PSA can be affected if i move my bowels. on the day, i was to have my blood drawn, i had to strain to move my bowels. so, i can't understand why he won't check for prostatitis and try to treat that as supposed to trying to find if it's cancer. i know that anything is possible, but on may 25th, my uro performed a DRE after blood was tested. he said my prostate felt smooth, but with a bit of enlargement. but that was to be expected considering my age [44]. so, i'm just notunderstanding.

Posts.Content: hello, everyone. i received a call from the urology office and my PSA went down from a 7.6 to a 6.2. because my PSA is still above 5.5 when it was first checked, my uro recommends a biopsy. my urologist understands since i had some concerns about him performing a DRE before having blood drawn, he doesn't mind re-checking my PSA. i asked the nurse about the results of the apifiny blood exam. she said those haven't come back, yet. i thought if the apifiny results were above a score of 59, that would be a reason to recommend a biopsy. so, i have a few concerns: 1. should i go ahead with the biopsy or wait 'til the apifiny results come back? 2. do you really think my uro performing a DRE before having blood drawn really caused my PSA to be 6.2? 3. since my uro recommends a biopsy with a 6.2 PSA, do you think he'll still recommend a biopsy if my apifiny results are under 59?

Posts.Title: My CBC Results With Respect to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: good people?! how are you guys on this day? i have a question i'd like to ask. what do you do when your second opinion is different from your first. i sent in a request for my pathology report to john epstein at john hopkins. today i received the results and here's what was written: A. benign fibromuscular tissue. B. PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA, GLEASON SCORE 3+3=6 (GRADE GROUP 1) DISCONTINUOUSLY INVOLVING 80% OF ONE [1] CORE C. PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA, GLEASON SCORE 3+3=6 (GRADE GROUP 1) INVOLVING 20% OF ONE [1] CORE now take a look at my signature and tell me what you think.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another I'm confused. How many samples we're taken and how many were sent to Epstein? 1. 6 of 8 cores were taken. all they told me was my biopsy slides were sent to epstein. so, i'm guessing all eight. secondly, everything you see is everything that was written on both pathology reports. i'm not here to ask someone to wipe my a-- and tell me what i want to hear. Originally Posted by Another Please complete your signature. What is your PSA, family, DRE, and symptom histories? Why are you testing at 43? Is this your first biopsy? How did you manage a 3T MRI fusion biopsy as your first? 2. i tried to complete my signature, but the damn thing will only allow 1,000 characters. my signature with respect to dates, diagnoses and procedures goes back to 2014. it won't allow me to put everything on here. i'm not hiding sh_t on purpose. i'm placing on here what i can. now if you know of a better organized way for me to place everything on here, please kindly show me, before accusing me of anything. my last psa was 11.9, up from 10.8 within a months span from june to july of 2018. i'm not testing at "43" i started at 40, because of an elevated psa [5.5] my first biopsy was in 2014. that was a TRUS biopsy that only found ASAP, BPH and prostatitis. so my old uro decided to monitor my psa. my 3T MRI fusion biopsy was not my first. Originally Posted by Another What does your doctor say? well, i only talk'd with my radio onco so far. he says bring in the results the next time i am to see him [apr. 24th] also he wants to take another look at my MRI. Originally Posted by Another ... Bottom line seems to be you asking for help while you are withholding. It usually implies an agenda or bias. if you knew the mileage and time it took to drive from south atlanta to peachtree dunwoody, you'd monitor those words. Y the h_ll would i travel that far to be biased? it's suits me better to just stay in denial and not do any damn thing at all, if that were the case. truth be written i thought the second opinion would've either confirmed or upgraded my diagnosis. this is why i'm so confused.
